trend: U.S. Drug Price Reform Targets Global Pharma Giants
summary: On May 13, 2025, President Donald Trump announced an executive order aimed at significantly reducing U.S. drug prices by up to 80%. The order seeks to match U.S. drug prices with those of the lowest in similarly developed countries through 'most favoured nation' pricing. This move impacts major pharmaceutical companies that rely heavily on U.S. revenues. Analysts anticipate legal challenges and implementation complexities.
source title: Trump vows drug price cuts with global impact

trend: Global Regulators Prioritize Climate Risk Assessment
summary: On May 12, 2025, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision announced plans to enhance the assessment of financial risks related to climate change. A voluntary disclosure framework is set to guide national regulators, aligning with European and British strategies. However, the U.S. has withdrawn from several climate-focused initiatives, indicating a regulatory divergence.
source title: Global banking regulators agree to prioritise climate risk work

trend: U.S. Groups Raced to Stockpile Pharmaceuticals Ahead of Tariffs
summary: In March 2025, U.S. imports of pharmaceuticals and medical industry products surged to a record $53 billion, a 160% increase from the previous year. This rush reflects fears among companies over potential tariffs from the Trump administration. Major pharmaceutical firms have announced multi-billion dollar investments to expand U.S. manufacturing capacity.
source title: Pharma companies stockpile as U.S. tariffs loom

trend: AI in Healthcare Market Projected to Reach $24.18 Billion
summary: The artificial intelligence in healthcare market size has grown exponentially in recent years. It will grow from $18.16 billion in 2024 to $24.18 billion in 2025 at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 33.2%. The growth is driven by increasing implementation of AI in radiology, cost-efficient drug discovery, and rising funding in AI healthcare.
source title: Artificial Intelligence In Healthcare Global Market Report

trend: Medical Costs Projected to Remain High Globally
summary: The WTW Global Medical Trends Survey reveals that medical costs are projected to remain high at a global average rate of 10.4% in 2025. Rising medical costs are driven by advancements in technology and pharmaceuticals, overwhelmed public healthcare systems, and increased private healthcare demand.

trend: U.S. Banking Sector Advocates for Easing Leverage Rules
summary: The U.S. banking industry is urging regulators to reform the Supplementary Leverage Ratio (SLR), a post-financial crisis rule requiring banks to hold capital even against low-risk assets like Treasury bonds. Regulatory bodies are considering adjustments, such as exempting Treasuries and central bank deposits or modifying the 'enhanced' SLR applicable to large banks.
source title: Banking sector says easing U.S. leverage rules could support Treasury market

trend: Asian Banks Experience Boost Amid Currency Rally
summary: A rally in Asian currencies, led by the Taiwan dollar and followed by currencies from China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, and South Korea, is strengthening Asian banks' wealth management and forex services. This shift is partly due to rising demand for local currency-denominated assets as investors move away from U.S. dollar assets amid heightened trade tariff uncertainties.
source title: Asian banks see big boost to wealth business as currencies rally

trend: Investment Banks Push More into Private Equity Amid Tariff Challenges
summary: New U.S. tariffs announced by President Donald Trump in April 2025 have significantly disrupted mergers and acquisitions (M&A), particularly affecting private equity firms. Despite the slump, investment banks are investing in their financial sponsors teams, betting on a long-term rebound.
source title: Trump tariffs ice deals but banks push into PE more

trend: Bank of England Cuts Interest Rates Amid Global Economic Uncertainty
summary: On May 8, 2025, the Bank of England reduced its main interest rate by 0.25 percentage points to 4.25%, marking the fourth rate cut since August. Governor Andrew Bailey cited easing inflationary pressures and global economic unpredictability—particularly stemming from U.S. tariff policies—as reasons for a cautious and gradual approach to further cuts.
source title: Bank of England cuts rates for fourth time

trend: Global Banking Industry Advances Toward Digital and Cashless Ecosystem
summary: The global banking industry is advancing toward a more digital and cashless ecosystem. Robust security systems and unwavering trust in transactions become paramount as banks navigate this transformation.
